TAPE SUPPLY
With the advent of the leg system and a continuing
increase in activity there developed a serious shortage of
tape. The program acceptance committee sent out a frantic
appeal to member stations asking them to come to the rescue
of the network. Thirteen stations responded nobly with a
total of 240 reels of tape. This combined with the supply
already in use makes a total of approximately 450 reels now
in the possession of the network. The word approximate is
used because there are still some tapes in circulation which have
never been in our possession. This supply has been adequate for
this interim period*
It is recommended that when the basic tape supply has
been obtained the stations making these contributions be repaid
in kind* Since this was not a general levy but a purely voluntary
act to help out in an emergency it seems fair to return the tapes
with our thankso
V;e have also undertaken to number all of the NAEB tapes*
This process, while somewhat tedious, facilitates the keeping of
a running inventory as well as making positive identification
easier*
One additional problem in connection with tape needs to
be mentioned* According to the engineers, it will be necessary
to standardize on tape for use with the mass duplicator. Apparently
the recording characteristics are not identical in different brands
of tape. Thus, when ten tapes are being dubbed at a tinfe the HP
of a standard tape is the only way of avoiding differences in
level and nuality*
